newsitem.title: USA: Rockwell delays shipping of some K56 modems.
newsitem.headline: Rockwell delays shipping of some K56 modems.

text.p: Rockwell Semiconductor Systems said Friday it has delayed shipping some of its newly introduced K56flex modem chipsets by up to two weeks while it makes improvements to the products.

The company said in a statement that the products affected are "client-side" modem chipsets used in PC or stand-alone end-user modems. Deliveries of the chipsets will be delayed by one to two weeks, while some software enhancements are made to improve modem performance.
The new modems chipsets allow users to download information from the Internet at 56 kilobits per second, about twice the speed of previously available modems.
Rockwell said its software upgradeable "central site" modem chipsets, used by Internet service providers, remain on schedule for production release by the end of March.

"Extensive field tests by our lead customers identified certain network configurations where performance improvements could be made," said Dwight Decker, president, Rockwell Semiconductor Systems. "This brief delay will result in a more robust client-side product and still not impact our overall schedule for end-to-end K56flex deployment."
